title: A Pilot Evaluation of Learning Skills Together: A Intervention to Teach Complex Care Skills to Caregivers of Persons Living With Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The Learning Skills Together (LST) program is a synchronous web-based educational intervention developed to address the essential need for training to equip family caregivers to someone with mid-stage Alzheimer's disease to confidently provide complex care tasks.The purpose of this pilot study is to evaluate the feasibility of delivering LST, the program's acceptability to caregivers, and likelihood of effecting caregivers self-efficacy and mastery.

groups.title: Learning Skills Together Intervention
groups.description:
Participants in the Learning Skills Together program will begin their participation with a one-on-one phone call with an interventionist, who will ensure the participant is prepared to to attend the group sessions (e.g., familiar with videoconference technology) and will help the participant to set individual goals. The caregiver participant will then attend 4, group-based sessions lasting approximately 1.5 hours each, to learn about common complex care tasks managed by family caregivers to someone with mid-stage Alzheimer's disease, such as managing behavioral symptoms of dementia, incontinence, nutrition, transferring, medication management, and more. Sessions will integrate interactive activities, such as videos, case studies, and discussions. Approximately four weeks later, caregivers will be asked to attend a group reflection session to discuss application of what was learned and progress in meeting individual goals.

Learning Skills Together: Information provided in arm/group description.

milestones.type: Attended at Least 2 Intervention Sessions in One Cohort

achievements.comment: Forty-one (41) participants enrolled and completed the baseline survey. Of those who completed the baseline survey, three participants did not attend at least two sessions. Three participants started the intervention in one cohort but completed it in another (off-protocol).
Of those 27 who completed the 8-week follow up survey, one participant skipped the 4-week follow up survey but completed the 8-week survey.

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: Baseline characteristics are described for the analysis population, which includes participants who were eligible according to initial criteria, but who also: 1) attended at least 2 program sessions and 2) completed the program in the same cohort (i.e., did not start in one cohort and complete "make up" sessions in the following cohort.

measures.title: Caregiver Competency
measures.description: Measured using the Caregiver Competency Scale, a 3 item scale. Each scale has 5 responses: Never (0), to All of the time (5). Scores range from 3-15 with a lower score indicating less confidence in providing for relative's needs.

measures.title: Caregiver Mastery
measures.description: Measured using the Caregiver Mastery Scale, a 7 item scale which asks the participant the extent to which they feel they have control over various parts of their lives. Responses range from Strongly Disagree (1) to Strongly Agree (4). Range of scores are from 7-28, with a lower score showing that the caregiver believes they have less control.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Caregiver Competency
outcomeMeasures.description: This will be measured using the Caregiving Competence Scale. This measure includes 3-items pertaining to caregiver's confidence (e.g., "I feel confident that I am meeting the needs of my relative"). There are five response options to each statement ("Strongly Disagree" \[1\] to "Strongly Agree" \[5\]), such that scores may range from 3 to 15. A lower score indicates a lower level of confidence that the caregiver is meeting their relative's needs (i.e., higher scores are better). The outcome measure will use the average change score from baseline scores.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Change from baseline to 4 weeks post-intervention; and to 8 weeks post-intervention

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Caregiver Mastery
outcomeMeasures.description: This will be measured using the Caregiver Mastery Scale. This 7-item scale asks participants the extent to which they feel they have control over various parts of their lives (e.g., "I have little control over the things that happen to me"). Participants may respond that they "Strongly Disagree (1) to Strongly agree (4) with each statement, such that scores range from 7 to 28. The lower the score, the less control the caregiver feels that they have control (i.e., higher scores are better). The mean score for this measure among caregivers to frail older adults was previously reported as 19.42 (SD 3.29), with Cronbach's alpha of 0.78. The outcome measure will use the average change score from baseline scores.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Change from baseline to 4 weeks post-intervention; and to 8 weeks post-intervention

otherEvents.term: Adverse Event: Identification of Severe Depression
otherEvents.notes: This event pertains to caregivers who were identified during any measurement occasion as having severe depression. It is not known whether high depression scores were related to study participation.

limitationsAndCaveats.description:
Application of a. pre- and post-test design means that changes in self-efficacy cannot be attributed to the intervention alone

Results from this study are subject to selection bias given participant dropout between survey collection times

The small size of the analytic sample may have contributed to Type II error for some outcomes

explanation_target: Reason: The described intervention (Learning Skills Together, LST) is a synchronous web-based psychoeducational program that teaches family caregivers how to provide complex care and aims to improve caregiver self-efficacy and mastery — i.e., a behavioral/educational intervention, not a pharmacologic agent. citeturn1search3turn1search2

Act: Key extracted details — program name: Learning Skills Together (LST); format: synchronous/group videoconference psychoeducational sessions (pilot: 4 weeks; later RCT protocol describes 6 weeks); target population: family caregivers of persons with mid-stage Alzheimer’s disease; primary aims: feasibility, acceptability, and improving caregiver self-efficacy/competence (no drug, biologic, or placebo involved). citeturn1search0turn1search3
